creditline: The Friends of Bruce Dayton Art Acquisitions Fund
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: two figures on small bridge at LL walking towards open pavilion within a small grove of trees; robed figure on trail at lower center approaches pavilion; towering, bulbous rock formation in background at R; waterway and richly foliated landscape
markings: URC; sticker on L roller end: [Chu Tuan/2925]; sticker R roller end: [3]
text: Although of small scale, the spirit of monumentality in this painting references landscapes painted during China’s Northern Song dynasty. The tall pines and primary reliance on ink-tonality to define rock and mountain forms are hallmarks of the school of painting begun by Li Cheng (919-967) and developed by Guo Xi (c. 1020 – c. 1090) of the Northern Song dynasty. Zhu Duan’s landscape, created during closing years of the 15th century, serves to show the continuation of this dominant and enduring tradition.
title: Meeting Along the River
